author: @expat2010
text: I started learning databases and VBA when I was around 50, almost 30 years ago. Worked both fulltime but mostly freelancing. I've been studying Python for a year or so, mostly because I love it but I've  also picked up several simple freelance jobs.   So while I refuse jobs now I would have taken decades ago because they are just too complex and exhausting, still, 79 years old, self taught, (well, help from people like Corey!) , I'm a productive programmer. My suggestion is that if you feel for one reason or another  you will not be successful in a highly competitive market, find a niche out of the mainstream that you enjoy, that you are passionate about. If you love it, - hate to break away from studying or working through problems even to eat or sleep, you will be good enough to be productive. Don't compare yourself to the best - you don't have to be best. And you don't have to be "well rounded" if you find a niche that does not have a lot of competition.

author: @Sauhros
text: Im 22 years old and I started learning python because one of my university's business professors recommended I get exposed to it if I wanted to do market research as my major's emphasis. I have to say I'm grateful for it because like Corey said it has opened my eyes to a lifetime of learning and I am just absolutely thrilled because of it. Although,  I sometimes feel overwhelmed because I feel lost that I'm learning so much and still don't really know how to apply all the concepts together, the hunger and passion to find where things connect drive me. Thank you so much Corey you are a magnificent person your doing so much for everyone who watches your videos and I just wanna take the time to recognize your commitment. Keep on learning everyone its never too late!

author: @bowenwang
text: I am from China and I am a Java and JavaScript developer. In the last week I have begun learning Python by myself and I found your channel. The first video I saw was List comprehensions. Your explanations were so clear and easily understandable and I almost finished all your videos relating to Python. I have exactly the same experience as you do. I majored in computer science at college but did not find it interesting and I considered finding another job after graduation. But now I really enjoy coding and sometimes I regret wasting so much time at college. So I work hard everyday trying my best to catch up but most importantly I like what I am doing and thank myself for letting me entering the amazing programming world.

author: @vishnumu108
text: As a full-time Python developer I use and recommend pyscripter on Windows platform. It supports awesome debugger, themes, custom add-ons. It's ultra light weight. Rock solid.  I have tried Pycharm and a fan of its UI. But it's heavy, Supports integrated versioning. flexibility vs complication is low compared to pyscripter.

author: @SHONNER
text: So many good IDEs out there. I use Eclipse right now because I can use it with various languages other than Python. I'm in Windows 10, and do 32-bit apps.  Again, so many good Python books out there. The trick is getting the book for the version of Python you'll be using. I still use Python 2.5 (ca. 2008) because of all the libraries I like working in that were available at that time. I don't do any web app stuff obviously. Just standalone EXE apps for Windows.
